pullRequest.title: [0.10] Support Smithy IDL Serialization
pullRequest.bodyText:
This adds the ability to take an in-memory model and serialize it into the Smithy IDL format.

commit.message:
Add writeInline method to CodeWriter

This adds a method to CodeWriter which allow for writing without
having a trailing newline or leading indentation inserted. This can
be very useful when you want to write part of a line without knowing
what the whole line will contain.

This does preserve some safety in that it will intercept newlines to
treat them as normal, but it is still potentially dangerous if not
used carefully.

Support Smithy IDL serialization

This adds support for serializing a Smithy model into the IDL format.

nodes.bodyText:
Can you add some predicates to this, similar to the SmithyModelSerializer?
These kinds of predicates are different than model transformations because they are only controlling what gets serialized and not removing shapes from the model. This is important because when the transformer removes shapes, it actually ensures that any references to the shape are automatically removed. This is super important because if a shape that defines a trait is removed, all instances of that trait being applied to other shapes is also removed. There are use cases where we might want to serialize all trait applications but not trait definitions (like maybe you're pulling the traits in as a dependency, but still using the traits).
This seems like it could use some more description -- what's in the map? Are the paths relative?
What happens if a model only contains metadata? Seems like it would do nothing.
Note that a model might contain only metadata, and metadata occurs before a namespace is declared.

namespace should either be omitted somehow or just set to null. There's no "current namespace" when control statements or metadata statements are being defined. All shape IDs referenced in metadata need to be absolute actually, otherwise they refer to the prelude. With the current setup, I think metadata that contains shape IDs that refer to shapes in the passed in namespace would be converted to relative shape IDs, thus making them invalid.
Would a case-insensitive order make the result non-deterministic for keys with the same case-insenstive value?
I thought blank line trimming defaulted to allowing one blank line? Maybe there's a bug in the CodeWriter?

This probably needs docs to describe how it works.
Also, should we use nested directories, or just flat files like what you have here?
Does this need to be public?

I think structures should come before unions... Ideally, input and output structures, followed by errors, followed by other structures? I dunno... maybe there's a nice way to implement a kind of newspaper sorting where there first time a shape is referred to be an aggregate shape it's the next shape written?
Nit: there's usually a space between description and params/return value.
Why not public?
Nice! I didn't know this existed

commit.message: Add filtering predicates to idl serializer

Don't filter metadata case-insensitively

Shapes can be filtered case-insensitively because they are required
to be case-insensitively unique. Metadata doesn't have that same
constraint though, so filtering them as such would lead to a non-
deterministic ordering.
Clarify documentation on IDL serializer outputs
Sort structures before unions in serialized IDL

commit.message:
Simplify IDL serializer

This simplifies various bits of the internals, for instance by
discarding much manual tinkering of sorting.
Add a base path to the idl serializer

Compare ShapeId's case-insensitively

This updates the `compareTo` on shapeIds to be case-insensitve by
default, with a case-sensitive tie-breaker. Though technically that
means we could be comparing a given shape twice, practically the
likelihood is low since ShapeId's in a model must be
case-insensitively unique.
